awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: From 21 cm Observations to Precision Reionization Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this program is to study the epoch of reionization (EoR) through the redshifted hydrogen emission line at rest wavelength 21 cm. The EoR is one of the last unexplored phases in the history of the universe. Broader impacts of the work include training of women and underrepresented minority students through a program called Research Experiences for Non-Traditional Undergraduates (RENTU). 

The award will provide support for the US-based imaging power spectrum analysis team, which has been at the forefront of analyzing data from the Mileura Widefield Array telescope in Australia, and will provide one of the cornerstone analysis pipelines for the new Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA), an NSF-supported radio telescope in South Africa.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the work of the most successful international team trying to observe the Universe’s first stars as they burned away the primordial hydrogen fog 13 billion years ago.  Known as 21 cm observations of the Epoch of Reionization, this team uses data taken with the Murchison Widefield Array radio telescope in the remote Australian outback. These observations of the Epoch of Reionization are one of the grand challenges of modern astronomy, and were recently identified as the ‘discovery area’ in cosmology by the ASTRO2020 Decadal Survey.

Specific products of this grant include:

- Some of the deepest observations of the Epoch of Reionization to date (Barry et al. 2019a, Li et al. 2019, Wilensky et al. in prep.)

- Legacy map of diffuse polarized emission across the southern galactic cap (Byrne et al. 2022). These maps are important both for precision calibration of Reionization observations and provide a unprecedented view of the high synchrotron clouds in our own galaxy.

- Open development of the reference Epoch of Reionization analysis pipeline (Barry et al. 2019b; Byrne et al. in review). All the tools for this analysis are both open source and developed in the open, forming the reference precision implementation for the field. 

- Thirteen peer reviewed publications and numerous talks at international conferences

The grant directly supported three physics PhD students and the innovative RENTU undergraduate research program for CC transfer students. The University of Washington Radio Cosmology group was majority women and URM during the duration of this grant.


Last Modified: 02/24/2022
Modified by: Miguel F Morales
